   &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 16%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;1,286,786&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 16%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;1,859,474&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Allowance for doubtful accounts&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;(611,353&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;(232,416&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCEEFF&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Accounts receivable, net&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;675,433&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;1,627,058&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;i&gt;Concentrations of Credit Risk&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Financial instruments which potentially subject&#13;the Company to concentrations of credit risk consist principally of cash on deposit with financial institutions and accounts receivable.&#13;At times, the Company&amp;#8217;s cash in banks is in excess of the FDIC insurance limit. The Company has not experienced any loss&#13;as a result of these cash deposits. These cash balances are maintained with one bank. The Company is exposed to credit risk with&#13;regard to two customers who accounted for 18% and 10%, or 28% in the aggregate, as of December 31, 2017, and one customer who accounted&#13;for 46% of the Company&amp;#8217;s trade receivables as of December 31, 2016. The Company does not generally require collateral or&#13;other security to support customer receivables.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;The Company monitors its exposure for credit losses and maintains&#13;allowances for anticipated losses, as required.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Inventories &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company&amp;#8217;s inventory includes raw&#13;materials such as bottles, sweeteners, labels, flavors and packaging. Finished goods inventory consists of bottled iced tea, lemonade&#13;and ALO Juice. As of December 31, 2017 and 2016, included in inventory was finished goods inventory with a cost, net of inventory&#13;reserve, of approximately $201,000 and $320,000, respectively, which has been delivered to one or more of the Company&amp;#8217;s distributors&#13;and is held in inventory until certain revenue recognition criteria are met.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0 0.5pt 0 0&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company values its inventories at the lower&#13;of cost or net realizable value. Cost is determined using the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method. As of December 31, 2017 and 2016,&#13;the Company recorded inventory reserves, of $200,775 and $45,078, respectively, to reduce the cost of certain products to estimated&#13;net realizable value. The following table summarizes inventories as of the dates presented:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 12pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=6 style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;As of&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;December 31, 2017&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;December 31, 2016&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCEEFF&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 58%; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Finished goods&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 18%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;934,087&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 18%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;905,642&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Raw materials and supplies&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;664,528&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;282,299&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCEEFF&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Total inventories&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;1,598,615&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;1,187,941&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Property and Equipment&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Property and equipment is recorded at cost.&#13;Major property additions, replacements, and betterments are capitalized, while maintenance and repairs that do not extend the useful&#13;lives of an asset or add new functionality are expensed as incurred. Depreciation is recorded using the straight-line method over&#13;the respective estimated useful lives of the Company&amp;#8217;s assets.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The estimated useful lives typically are 3&#13;years for cold-drink containers, such as reusable fridges, wood racks, vending machines, barrels, and coolers, and are depreciated&#13;using the straight-line method over the estimated useful life of each group of equipment, as determined using the group-life method.&#13;Under this method, the Company does not recognize gains or losses on the disposal of individual units of equipment when the disposal&#13;occurs in the normal course of business. The Company capitalizes the costs of refurbishing its cold-drink containers and depreciates&#13;those costs over the estimated period until the next scheduled refurbishment or until the equipment is retired. The estimated useful&#13;lives are typically 3 to 5 years for office furniture and equipment and are depreciated on a straight-line basis. The estimated&#13;useful lives for trucks and automobiles are typically 3 to 5 years and are depreciated on a straight line basis.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Intangible Assets &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;As of December 31, 2017 and 2016, the Company&#13;tested the domain name utilizing the qualitative method. Based on this analysis, it was determined that there were no indicators&#13;of impairment as of December 31, 2017 and 2016.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;During September 2017, the Company recorded&#13;an indefinite lived intangible asset representing for the value of the ALO Juice intellectual property. However, at December 31,&#13;2017, the Company tested the fair value of the ALO intangible asset and determined that it was fully impaired as of such date,&#13;because the Company has de-emphasized the sale of its ALO business in order to better manage its liquidity. During the year ended&#13;December 31, 2017, the Company recorded a charge of $150,000 as an impairment of this intangible asset.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Intangible assets with finite useful lives&#13;are amortized over their expected useful life. Intangible assets with useful lives are tested for impairment when circumstances&#13;indicate that there could be an impairment. Intangible assets with finite useful lives include website development costs with a&#13;net book value of $0 and $2,500 as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively. The estimated useful life of the capitalized costs&#13;of the Company&amp;#8217;s website was 3 years and was depreciated on a straight line basis. As of December 31, 2017, the cost of the&#13;website development was $15,000 and the accumulated amortization was $15,000. As of December 31, 2016, the cost of the website&#13;development was $15,000 and the accumulated amortization was $12,500. For the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016, amortization&#13;expense was $2,500 and $4,994, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;i&gt;Deferred Financing Costs &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company capitalizes issuance costs related&#13;to lines of credit as deferred financing costs. The Company amortizes the deferred financing costs over the term of the line of&#13;credit.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;i&gt;Income Taxes&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company accounts for income taxes in accordance&#13;with FASB ASC 740, &amp;#8220;Income Taxes&amp;#8221; (&amp;#8220;ASC 740&amp;#8221;). ASC 740 requires an asset and liability approach for financial&#13;accounting and reporting for income taxes and established for all the entities a minimum threshold for financial statement recognition&#13;of the benefit of tax positions, and requires certain expanded disclosures. The provision for income taxes is based upon income&#13;or loss after adjustment for those permanent items that are not considered in the determination of taxable income. Deferred income&#13;taxes represent the tax effects of differences between the financial reporting and tax basis of the Company&amp;#8217;s assets and&#13;liabilities at the enacted tax rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse. The Company evaluates&#13;the recoverability of deferred tax assets and establishes a valuation allowance when it is more likely than not that some portion&#13;or all the deferred tax assets will not be realized. Management makes judgments as to the interpretation of the tax laws that might&#13;be challenged upon an audit and cause changes to previous estimates of tax liability. In management&amp;#8217;s opinion, adequate provisions&#13;for income taxes have been made. If actual taxable income by tax jurisdiction varies from estimates, additional allowances or reversals&#13;of reserves may be necessary.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Based on the Company&amp;#8217;s evaluation, it&#13;has been concluded that there are no significant uncertain tax positions requiring recognition in the Company&amp;#8217;s consolidated&#13;financial statements. The evaluation was performed for the 2017 and 2016 tax years. The Company believes that its income tax positions&#13;and deductions will be sustained on audit and does not anticipate any adjustments that will result in a material change to its&#13;financial position or results of operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company&amp;#8217;s policy for recording interest&#13;and penalties associated with tax audits is to record such items as a component of income tax expense. There were no amounts accrued&#13;for penalties and interest for years ended December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016. The Company does not expect its uncertain tax&#13;position to change during the next twelve months. Management is currently unaware of any issues under review that could result&#13;in significant payments, accruals or material deviations from its position.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On December 22, 2017, the U.S. government enacted&#13;comprehensive tax legislation commonly referred to as the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the &amp;#8220;Tax Act&amp;#8221;). The Tax Act makes&#13;broad and complex changes to the U.S. tax code that potentially will affect the Company&amp;#8217;s fiscal year ending December 31,&#13;2018.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The changes included in the Tax Act are broad&#13;and complex. The final transition impacts of the Tax Act are difficult to assess, due to, among other things, changes in interpretations&#13;of the Tax Act, any legislative action to address questions that arise because of the Tax Act, any changes in accounting standards&#13;for income taxes or related interpretations in response to the Tax Act, or any updates or changes to estimates the company has&#13;utilized to calculate the transition impact. The SEC has issued rules that would allow for a measurement period of up to one year&#13;after the enactment date of the Tax Act to finalize the recording of the related tax impacts (See Note 10).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Stock Based Compensation&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company accounts for stock based compensation&#13;in accordance with ASC 718, Compensation - Stock Compensation (&amp;#8220;ASC 718&amp;#8221;). ASC 718 establishes accounting for stock-based&#13;awards exchanged for employee services. Under the provisions of ASC 718, stock based compensation cost is measured at the grant&#13;date, based on the fair value of the award, and is recognized as expense over the employee&amp;#8217;s requisite service period (generally&#13;the vesting period of the equity grant). The fair value of the Company&amp;#8217;s common stock options are estimated using the Black&#13;Scholes option-pricing model with the following assumptions: expected volatility, dividend rate, risk free interest rate and the&#13;expected life. The Company calculates the expected volatility using the historical volatility of the Company over the most recent&#13;period equal to the expected term and evaluates the extent to which available information indicates that future volatility may&#13;differ from historical volatility. The expected dividend rate is zero as the Company does not expect to pay or declare any cash&#13;dividends on common stock. The risk-free rates for the expected terms of the stock options are based on the U.S. Treasury yield&#13;curve in effect at the time of the grant. The Company has not experienced significant exercise activity on stock options. Due to&#13;the lack of historical information, the Company determined the expected term of its stock option awards issued using the simplified&#13;method.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The simplified method assumes each vesting&#13;tranche of the award has a term equal to the midpoint between when the award vests and when the award expires. The Company expenses&#13;stock-based compensation by using the straight-line method.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company accounts for stock options granted&#13;to consultants pursuant to the accounting guidance included in ASC 505-50 &amp;#8220;Equity-Based Payments to Non-Employees&amp;#8221;&#13;(&amp;#8220;ASC 505-50&amp;#8221;). Stock-based compensation cost is measured at the grant date and at the end of each reporting period&#13;for unvested awards, based on the fair value of the award, and is recognized as expense over the consultant&amp;#8217;s requisite service&#13;period (generally the vesting period of the equity grant). The fair value of the Company&amp;#8217;s stock options granted to consultants&#13;are estimated using the Black Scholes option-pricing model with the following assumptions: expected volatility, dividend rate,&#13;risk free interest rate and the expected life.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;In accordance with ASC 505-50, the Company&#13;recorded adjustments at the end of each reporting period to reflect the mark-to-market adjustment of the fair value of unvested&#13;awards granted to consultants. In connection with the mark-to-market adjustments at December 31, 2017, the Company utilized the&#13;closing price of the Company&amp;#8217;s common stock, as quoted on the NASDAQ Stock Market LLC (&amp;#8220;Nasdaq&amp;#8221;), as an input&#13;to the Black Scholes option-pricing model for the fair value of its common stock.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Loss per share&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Basic net loss per common share is computed&#13;by dividing net loss by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding. Diluted earnings per share reflect, in periods&#13;in which they have a dilutive effect, the impact of common shares issuable upon the exercise of stock options, warrants and the&#13;conversion. The computation of diluted earnings per share excludes those with an exercise price in excess of the average market&#13;price of the Company&amp;#8217;s common shares during the periods presented. The computation of diluted earnings per share excludes&#13;outstanding options, warrants and other dilutive instruments in periods where the inclusion of such instruments would be antidilutive,&#13;as provided below:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 12pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=6 style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;As of December 31,&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;2017&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;2016&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCEEFF&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 62%&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Options to purchase common stock&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 16%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;550,534&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 16%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;425,411&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Warrants to purchase common stock&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;1,534,320&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;470,570&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCEEFF&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Total potentially dilutive securities&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;2,084,854&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;895,981&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Fair Value of Financial Instruments&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The carrying amounts of cash, short term investments,&#13;accounts receivable, automobile and equipment loans approximate fair value due to the short-term nature of these instruments. In&#13;addition, for notes payable, the Company believes that interest rates approximate prevailing rates.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;ASC 820 &amp;#8220;Fair Value Measurements and&#13;Disclosures&amp;#8221; provides the framework for measuring fair value. That framework provides a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes&#13;the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value. The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices&#13;in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (level 1 measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (level&#13;3 measurements).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Fair value is defined as an exit price, representing&#13;the amount that would be received upon the sale of an asset or payment to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between&#13;market participants. Fair value is a market-based measurement that is determined based on assumptions that market participants&#13;would use in pricing an asset or liability. A three-tier fair value hierarchy is used to prioritize the inputs in measuring fair&#13;value as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Level 1 Quoted prices in active markets for&#13;identical assets or liabilities.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Level 2 Quoted prices for similar assets or&#13;liabilities in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in markets that are not active, or&#13;other inputs that are observable, either directly or indirectly.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Level 3 Significant unobservable inputs that&#13;cannot be corroborated by market data.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Fair values for short-term money market investments&#13;are determined from quoted prices in active markets for these money market funds, and are considered to be Level 1.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The carrying value of financial instruments&#13;in the Company&amp;#8217;s consolidated financial statements are as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 12pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Quoted Prices in &lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Active Markets for&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Identical Assets or &lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Liabilities &lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;(Level 1)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Quoted Prices for&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Similar Assets or&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Liabilities in&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Active Markets&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;(Level 2)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Significant&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Unobservable&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Inputs &lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;(Level 3)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1.5pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCEEFF&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 43%; padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Short-term investments at December 31, 2017&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%; padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%; border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 16%; border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;-&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%; padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%; padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%; border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 16%; border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;-&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%; padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%; padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%; border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 16%; border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%; padding-bottom: 1.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: right&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: right&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: right&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCEEFF&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Short-term investments at December 31, 2016&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;2,389,521&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;-&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Recent Accounting Standards&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;In January 2016, the Financial Accounting Standards&#13;Board (&amp;#8220;FASB&amp;#8221;), issued Accounting Standards Update (&amp;#8220;ASU&amp;#8221;) 2016-01, &amp;#8220;Financial Instruments-Overall&#13;(Subtopic 825-10): Recognition and Measurement of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities,&amp;#8221; which amends the guidance&#13;in U.S. generally accepted accounting principles on the classification and measurement of financial instruments. Changes to the&#13;current guidance primarily affect the accounting for equity investments, financial liabilities under the fair value option, and&#13;the presentation and disclosure requirements for financial instruments. In addition, the ASU clarifies guidance related to the&#13;valuation allowance assessment when recognizing deferred tax assets resulting from unrealized losses on available-for-sale debt&#13;securities. The new standard is effective for fiscal years and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2017, and is to be&#13;adopted by means of a cumulative-effect adjustment to the balance sheet at the beginning of the first reporting period in which&#13;the guidance is effective. Early adoption is not permitted except for the provision to record fair value changes for financial&#13;liabilities under the fair value option resulting from instrument-specific credit risk in other comprehensive income. The Company&#13;expects that the adoption of the ASU will not have a material impact upon the Company consolidated financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;In February 2016, the FASB issued new lease&#13;accounting guidance (ASU No. 2016-02, Leases). Under the new guidance, at the commencement date, lessees will be required to recognize&#13;a lease liability, which is a lessee&amp;#8217;s obligation to make lease payments arising from a lease, measured on a discounted basis;&#13;and a right-of use asset, which is an asset that represents the lessee&amp;#8217;s right to use, or control the use of, a specified&#13;asset for the lease term. The new guidance is not applicable for leases with a term of 12 months or less. Lessor accounting is&#13;largely unchanged. Public business entities should apply the amendments in ASU 2016-02 for fiscal years beginning after December&#13;15, 2018, including interim periods within those fiscal years. Early application is permitted upon issuance. Lessees (for capital&#13;and operating leases) and lessors (for sales-type, direct financing, and operating leases) must apply a modified retrospective&#13;transition approach for leases existing at, or entered into after, the beginning of the earliest comparative period presented in&#13;the financial statements. The modified retrospective approach would not require any transition accounting for leases that expired&#13;before the earliest comparative period presented. Lessees and lessors may not apply a full retrospective transition approach. The&#13;Company is currently evaluating the impact the adoption of this standard will have on its consolidated financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09,&#13;Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606) which has subsequently been amended by ASU 2015-14, ASU 2016-08, ASU 2016-10,&#13;ASU 2016-12, and ASU 2017-13. These ASUs outline a single comprehensive model for entities to use in accounting for revenue arising&#13;from contracts with customers and supersedes most current revenue recognition guidance, including industry-specific guidance. The&#13;guidance includes a five-step framework that requires an entity to: (i) identify the contract(s) with a customer, (ii) identify&#13;the performance obligations in the contract, (iii) determine the transaction price, (iv) allocate the transaction price to the&#13;performance obligations in the contract, and (v) recognize revenue when the entity satisfies a performance obligation. In July&#13;2015, the FASB deferred the effective date of ASU 2014-09 to annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017. Early&#13;adoption will be permitted as of annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016, including interim reporting periods&#13;within those annual periods. A full retrospective or modified retrospective approach is required. In addition, the new guidance&#13;will require enhanced disclosures, including revenue recognition policies to identify performance obligations to customers and&#13;significant judgments in measurement and recognition.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company has elected to apply the modified&#13;retrospective method and the impact was determined to be immaterial on the consolidated financial statements. Accordingly, the&#13;new revenue standard will be applied prospectively in our consolidated financial statements from January 1, 2018 forward and reported&#13;financial information for historical comparable periods will not be revised and will continue to be reported under the accounting&#13;standards in effect during those historical periods.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company has performed an analysis and identified&#13;its revenues and costs that are within the scope of the new guidance. The Company anticipates that its current methods of recognizing&#13;revenues will not be significantly impacted by the new guidance.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;In January 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017-01,&#13;&amp;#8220;Clarifying the Definition of a Business&amp;#8221; (&amp;#8220;ASU 2017-01&amp;#8221;), which provides guidance to assist entities with&#13;evaluating whether transactions should be accounted for as acquisitions (or disposals) of assets or businesses. ASU 2017-01 requires&#13;entities to use a screen test to determine when an integrated set of assets and activities is not a business or if the integrated&#13;set of assets and activities needs to be further evaluated against the framework. ASU 2017-01 is effective for fiscal years beginning&#13;after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within those years. The Company believes that the adoption of the ASU may have&#13;an impact on the Company as it pursues its strategy to develop the blockchain business.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;In May 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-09&#13;&amp;#8220;Compensation-Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Scope of Modification Accounting&amp;#8221; (&amp;#8220;ASU 2017-09&amp;#8221;). The amendments&#13;in this update provide guidance about which changes to the terms or conditions of a share-based payment award require an entity&#13;to apply modification accounting in Topic 718. An entity should account for the effects of a modification unless all of the following&#13;are met: The fair value of the modified award is the same as the fair value of the original award immediately before the original&#13;award is modified, the vesting conditions of the modified award are the same as the vesting conditions of the original award immediately&#13;before the original award is modified and the classification of the modified award of an equity instrument or a liability instrument&#13;is the same as the classification of the original award immediately before the original award is modified. The provisions of this&#13;update are effective for annual and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2017, with early adoption permitted. The Company&#13;expects that the adoption of the ASU will not have a material impact upon the Company&amp;#8217;s consolidated financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Management&amp;#8217;s Evaluation of Subsequent Events&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;The following table classifies the US government securities by maturity:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 12pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 12pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;b&gt;NOTE 1 &amp;#8211; BUSINESS ORGANIZATION, LIQUIDITY AND GOING CONCERN&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Business Organization &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Long Blockchain Corp., (formerly known as Long&#13;Island Iced Tea Corp.) a Delaware corporation (&amp;#8220;LBCC&amp;#8221;), was formed on December 23, 2014. LBCC is the parent of Long&#13;Island Brand Beverages LLC (&amp;#8220;LIBB&amp;#8221;) (its operating subsidiary) and Cullen Agricultural Holding Corp. (&amp;#8220;Cullen&amp;#8221;)&#13;(collectively the &amp;#8220;Company&amp;#8221;).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Overview&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Since May 27, 2015, the Company&amp;#8217;s&#13;operations have consisted principally of a beverage business, focused on serving the ready-to-drink segment of the market. On&#13;December 21, 2017, the Company announced that it was expanding its attention to include the exploration of, and investment&#13;in, opportunities that leverage the benefits of blockchain technology. The Company changed its name from &amp;#8220;Long Island&#13;Iced Tea Corp.&amp;#8221; to &amp;#8220;Long Blockchain Corp.&amp;#8221; and reserved the web domain www.longblockchain.com. The Company&#13;also changed its trading symbol from &amp;#8220;LTEA&amp;#8221; to &amp;#8220;LBCC&amp;#8221; in connection with this name change. At such&#13;time, the Company announced that it would continue to operate the beverage business.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On February 20, 2018, in connection with the&#13;pivot of the Company&amp;#8217;s operation toward Blockchain, Mr. Philip Thomas, the Company&amp;#8217;s President and Chief Executive&#13;Officer (&amp;#8220;CEO&amp;#8221;) resigned and simultaneously, the Company&amp;#8217;s board of directors appointed Mr. Shamyl Malik, who&#13;was appointed to the Company&amp;#8217;s Board of Directors during December 2017, as CEO. The Company announced that it would seek&#13;to spin out the beverage business to the Company&amp;#8217;s shareholders (&amp;#8220;Beverage Spin Out&amp;#8221;). On February 12, 2018,&#13;in connection with the Beverage Spin Out, the Company formed Long Island Iced Tea Corp., a Delaware corporation. Further, the board&#13;of directors appointed three members of its board to provide oversight of the beverage operations (&amp;#8220;Beverage Committee&amp;#8221;).&#13;From this date until the consummation of the Beverage Spin Out, Mr. Thomas, under the direction of the Beverage Committee, shall&#13;provide day to day operational control and management of the beverage business.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;The Blockchain Business&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On December 21, 2017, the Company&#13;announced that it was expanding its attention to include the exploration of, and investment in, opportunities that leverage&#13;the benefits of blockchain technology.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company&amp;#8217;s management has been pursuing&#13;and evaluating investments, ventures, alliances and other strategic relationships in the blockchain space. On March 15, 2018, LBCC&#13;entered into an agreement to acquire the outstanding shares of Hashcove Limited, an early stage UK-based technology company focused&#13;on developing and deploying globally scalable distributed ledger technology solutions. The Company is conducting further diligence&#13;and is targeting to consummate the acquisition within the third quarter of 2018. During January 2018, the Company had entered into&#13;an agreement to purchase equipment for a crypto currency mining operation, however, the Company was not able to raise the capital&#13;to consummate this transaction. On March 19, 2018 and March 22, 2018 the company closed on the purchase of non-controlling interest&#13;of Stater Blockchain Limited and TSLC PTE Ltd., respectively (See Note 16).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;The Beverage Business&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company&amp;#8217;s beverage business is engaged&#13;in the production and distribution of premium Non-Alcoholic ready-to-drink (&amp;#8220;NARTD&amp;#8221;) beverages. The beverage business&#13;is currently organized under its flagship brand, Long Island Iced Tea, a premium NARTD tea made from a proprietary recipe and with&#13;quality components. The mission of the beverage business is to provide consumers with premium beverages offered at an affordable&#13;price.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Through its beverage business, the Company&#13;aspires to provide iced tea beverages that are convenient and appealing to consumers. There are two major target markets for Long&#13;Island Iced Tea: &amp;#8220;consumers on the go&amp;#8221; and &amp;#8220;health conscious consumers.&amp;#8221; &amp;#8220;Consumers on the go&amp;#8221;&#13;are families, employees, students and other consumers who lead a busy lifestyle. With increasingly hectic and demanding schedules,&#13;there is a need for products that are accessible and readily available. &amp;#8220;Health conscious consumers&amp;#8221; are individuals&#13;who are becoming more interested and better educated on what is included in their diets, causing them to shift away from the less&#13;healthy options, such as carbonated soft drinks, towards alternative beverages such as iced tea.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Through its beverage business, the Company&#13;produces a 100% brewed iced tea, using black tea leaves, purified water and natural cane sugar or sucralose. Flavors change from&#13;time to time, and have included lemon, peach, raspberry, guava, mango, diet lemon, diet peach, sweet tea, green tea and honey,&#13;half tea and half lemonade. The Company also offers lower calorie iced tea in flavor options that include mango, raspberry and&#13;peach. The Company also sells its iced tea in gallon bottles with flavor options including lemon, peach, green tea and honey, half&#13;and half lemonade, sweet tea, mango and unsweetened.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;During April 2017, the Company through its&#13;beverage business expanded its brand to include lemonade. Lemonade is offered in nine flavors including traditional, lime, pink&#13;lemonade, kiwi &amp;#38; strawberry, cherry, peach, watermelon, wild berries and strawberry and is offered at retail in 18oz. bottles.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company also distributes an aloe vera derived&#13;juice beverage (&amp;#8220;ALO Juice&amp;#8221;) in 500ml and 1.5 liter bottles. ALO Juice is offered in six flavors including original,&#13;pomegranate, mango, raspberry, pineapple and coconut. See below regarding the ALO Juice business. In addition, in order to service&#13;certain vending contracts, the Company sells snacks and other beverage products on a limited basis.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company sells its products to regional&#13;retail chains and to a mix of independent mid-to-large range distributors who in turn sell to retail outlets, such as big chain&#13;supermarkets, mass merchants, convenience stores, restaurants and hotels, principally in the New York, New Jersey, Connecticut&#13;and Pennsylvania markets, with additional distribution in Florida, Virginia, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and parts&#13;of the Midwest. As of December 31, 2017, the Company&amp;#8217;s products are available in approximately 21 states, the Caribbean and&#13;in Canada.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;The ALO Juice Business&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 36pt&gt;&lt;i&gt;Asset Purchase Agreement&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On December 8, 2016, the Company entered into&#13;an asset purchase agreement with The Wilnah International, LLC (&amp;#8220;Wilnah&amp;#8221;). Julio X. Ponce (&amp;#8220;Mr. Ponce&amp;#8221;)&#13;is the majority interest member of Wilnah and also the former owner of Seba Distribution LLC (&amp;#8220;Seba&amp;#8221;), a former distributor&#13;of ALO Juice. Pursuant to the agreement, the Company intended to acquire the intellectual property (&amp;#8220;IP&amp;#8221;) (trade names,&#13;formulas, recipes) for ALO Juice. During September 2017, the Company determined that it would license, rather than purchase the&#13;ALO Juice IP. Accordingly, on September 18, 2017, the Company terminated the asset purchase agreement with Wilnah.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 36pt&gt;&lt;i&gt;Licensing Agreement &amp;#8211; ALO Juice&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On September 18, 2017, the Company entered&#13;into an exclusive perpetual licensing agreement (&amp;#8220;Licensing Agreement&amp;#8221;) with Wilnah granting the Company the worldwide&#13;rights to produce, distribute and sell the ALO Juice brand. As compensation to Wilnah for these rights, the Company paid an initial&#13;fee of $150,000, which was applied against certain accounts receivable amounts due from Seba upon the closing and has agreed to&#13;pay to Wilnah a 7.0% royalty on the Company&amp;#8217;s gross sales of ALO Juice sales delivered to the Company&amp;#8217;s customers after&#13;the closing of this agreement (See Note 2 for a disclosure of impairment of this intangible asset).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 36pt&gt;&lt;i&gt;Employment Agreement&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Effective January 1, 2017, the Company had&#13;entered into an employment agreement with Mr. Ponce, to expand the Company&amp;#8217;s sales of Long Island branded products and ALO&#13;Juice products within the Southeast U.S. and Latin American regions. On September 1, 2017, the Company terminated the employment&#13;agreement of Mr. Ponce.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On September 1, 2017, the Company entered into&#13;a separation agreement (the &amp;#8220;Separation Agreement&amp;#8221;) with Mr. Ponce. Mr. Ponce received as compensation under the Separation&#13;Agreement a lump sum payment of $50,000, which was applied against the Seba accounts receivable.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 36pt&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 36pt&gt;&lt;i&gt;Sales Broker Agreement&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Effective September 1, 2017, the Company entered&#13;into a broker arrangement (&amp;#8220;Broker Arrangement&amp;#8221;) with Mr. Ponce, whereby Mr. Ponce will be paid a commission of 2.5%&#13;on net collected revenues from the sale of the Company&amp;#8217;s products (excluding ALO Juice) into certain distributor and retail&#13;relationships introduced by Mr. Ponce.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Liquidity and Going Concern&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;From inception, the Company has financed its&#13;operations through the issuance of debt and equity, and through utilizing trade credit with its vendors. The Company will require&#13;additional capital to fund the operating losses of the existing beverage business, as well as to fund the development of the blockchain&#13;business.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;As of December 31, 2017, the Company had cash&#13;of $370,947. As of December 31, 2017, the Company had a working capital deficit of $712,310. The Company incurred a net loss of&#13;$15,215,659 for the year ended December 31, 2017. As of December 31, 2017, the Company&amp;#8217;s stockholders&amp;#8217; deficit was&#13;$292,982.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On July 28 and 29, 2016, the Company sold 1,270,156&#13;shares of the Company&amp;#8217;s common stock in the July 2016 Offering. The sale of the shares generated gross proceeds of $6,985,858&#13;and net proceeds of $5,867,217 after deducting commissions and other offering expenses. On August 4, 2016, the July 2016 Offering&#13;was terminated. No further sales of shares were made in the July 2016 Offering.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On December 27, 2016, the Company consummated&#13;the December 2016 Offering of 406,550 shares of its common stock, through Network 1 and Dawson James Securities, Inc., as underwriters,&#13;pursuant to the terms of the underwriting agreement, dated December 21, 2016, with Network 1, as representative of the underwriters.&#13;The Shares were sold for a price to the public of $4.00 per share. The offering generated total net proceeds, after underwriting&#13;discounts and payment of other offering expenses, of $1,423,141.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On January 27, 2017, the Company sold 376,340&#13;shares of the Company&amp;#8217;s common stock in a public offering at an average price of $4.02 per share. Of the shares sold, 300,000&#13;were sold to the public at an offering price of $4.00 while the remaining 76,340 shares were sold to officers and directors of&#13;the Company at a price of $4.10 per share. The sale of common stock generated gross proceeds of $1,513,000 and net proceeds of&#13;$1,429,740 after deducting commissions and other offering expenses.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On June 14, 2017, the Company sold 256,848&#13;shares of the Company&amp;#8217;s common stock in a public offering at an average price of $5.06 per share. Of the shares sold, 231,850&#13;were sold to the public at an offering price of $5.00 while the remaining 24,998 shares were sold to officers and directors of&#13;the Company at a price of $5.60 per share. The sale of common stock generated gross proceeds of $1,299,250 and net proceeds of&#13;$1,259,415 after deducting commissions and other offering expenses.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On July 6, 2017, the Company sold 448,160 shares&#13;of the Company&amp;#8217;s common stock in a public offering at a price of $5.00 per share. Of the shares sold, 200,000 were sold to&#13;lead investors who, as a result of purchasing more than $500,000 in shares, each received (i) an additional number of shares of&#13;common stock equal to 7% of the total number of shares of common stock purchased by such lead investors in this offering (or an&#13;aggregate of 14,000 shares) and (ii) three-year warrants up to that number of shares of common stock equal to 20% of the total&#13;number of shares purchased by such lead investors in this offering (or warrants to purchase an aggregate of 40,000 shares). These&#13;warrants have an exercise price of $5.50 and were fully vested upon issuance. The sale of common stock generated gross proceeds&#13;of $2,240,800 and net proceeds of $2,134,487 after deducting commissions and other offering expenses.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On October 4, 2017, the Company sold 607,500&#13;shares of the Company&amp;#8217;s common stock in a public offering at a price of $2.05 per share. The Company received gross proceeds&#13;of $1,245,375 and net proceeds of $1,235,088 after deducting other offering expenses. Each investor in the offering also received&#13;a warrant to purchase 50% of the number of shares for which such investor subscribed in the offering (or a total aggregate number&#13;of shares underlying such warrants equal to 303,750 shares). The warrants have an exercise price of $2.40 per share, subject to&#13;adjustment, and expire one year from the closing of the offering.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Pursuant to a bridge financing agreement (&amp;#8220;Radium&#13;Agreement&amp;#8221;) dated November 27, 2017, the Company received cash of $750,000, less $7,500 of fees and expenses (See Note 6).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Pursuant to a Loan and Option Agreement (the&#13;&amp;#8220;Cavendish Loan Agreement&amp;#8221;) dated December 20, 2017, the Company has a borrowing facility of up to $4,000,000, subject&#13;to approval by the lender. During December 2017, the Company drew $750,000 under this arrangement, and during January 2018, the&#13;Company drew $1,250,000 under this arrangement (See Note 6).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Historically, the Company has financed its&#13;operations through the raising of equity capital and through trade credit with its vendors. The Company&amp;#8217;s ability to continue&#13;its operations and to pay its obligations when they become due is contingent upon the Company obtaining additional financing. Management&amp;#8217;s&#13;plans include raising additional funds through equity offerings, debt financings, or other means.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Basis of Presentation &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company determined the fair value of stock&#13;options granted based upon the assumptions as provided below.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 12pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The following tables summarize total stock-based&#13;compensation costs recognized for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 12pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Principles of Consolidation&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Use of Estimates&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;i&gt;Revenue Recognition&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Revenue is stated net of sales discounts and&#13;rebates paid to customers (See Customer Marketing Programs including Sign On and Sales Incentives, below). Net sales are recognized&#13;when all of the following conditions are met: (1) the price is fixed and determinable; (2) evidence of a binding arrangement exists&#13;(generally, purchase orders); (3) products have been delivered and there is no future performance required; and (4) amounts are&#13;collectible under normal payment terms.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;i&gt;Customer Marketing Programs, including Sign&#13;On and Sales Incentives&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Shipping and Handling Costs&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Advertising&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Research and Development &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The following table sets forth the available-for-sale&#13;securities, which were fully liquidated during the year ended December 31, 2017.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

   &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 10pt&gt;Unrealized&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;
